'''Robert Wadsworth Edgren''' (January 7, 1874 – September 9, 1939) was a nationally syndicated American political and sports cartoonist, reporter, editor and [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] athlete.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,762637,00.html?iid=chix-sphere "Milestones"], ''[[Time Magazine|Time]]'', Sep. 18, 1939[http://www.askart.com/AskART/artists/biography.aspx?searchtype=BIO&artist=11003196 Biography at AskART.com] ==Background== Edgren was born in [[Chicago, Illinois]].[http://www.wingedfist.com/cartoon_gallery.html Robert Edgren Cartoons] from the ''[[New York Evening World]]'', Winged Fist Organization During the 1890s Edgren studied at the Mark Hopkins Art Institute. Edgren attended the [[University of California]] at Berkeley where he was a member of the first Western track team to enter competitive events in the East.[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1895-04-27/ed-1/seq-8/ "Athletics"], ''[[The San Francisco Call]]'', page 8, April 7, 1895 He competed in the [[discus]] and [[shot put]] for the [[Athletics at the 1906 Summer Olympics|American Olympic team]] at the [[1906 Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens, Greece|Athens]].[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ed/robert-edgren-1.html SR Olympic Sports] ==Career== He began his journalism career in 1895 at the original [[Hearst Corporation|Hearst newspaper]], ''[[The San Francisco Examiner]]''. He was given the "inconsequential" job of a "handy man" with the ''Examiner'' but his work on the build-up to the historic 1897 [[List of heavyweight boxing champions|world heavyweight championship]] between [[Bob Fitzsimmons]] and [[James J. Corbett|"Gentleman Jim" Corbett]] launched his career. ==Political cartoonist== He was transferred to the Hearst paper in New York, ''[[The Evening Journal]]'', where he was appointed [[political cartoonist]]. He was dispatched to [[Cuba]] to cover the [[Spanish–American War]] in 1898. Reporting from the scenes of intense fighting, Edgren became famous for his "Sketches from Death," images of war atrocities that shocked readers of Hearst papers across America. When [[William Randolph Hearst]] himself told Edgren, "Don't exaggerate so much," an angered Edgren produced 500 photographs to prove the accuracy of his drawings. The images were eventually displayed before the [[United States Congress]], causing a sensation. Edgren was captured by the Spanish, who intended to try him in a military court, but the young reporter escaped and, disguised as a tugboat engineer, made his way to safety at [[Key West, Florida]]. ==Return to sports journalism== In 1904, Edgren was hired by [[Joseph Pulitzer]] as sports editor of ''[[The Evening World]]''. The position gave him a national readership, as his writings and "Miracle of Sports" cartoons[http://strippersguide.blogspot.com/2006/09/ep-1939-robert-edgren-obituary.html Robert Edgren Obituary] for ''[[Editor and Publisher]]'', 1939 were syndicated widely.[http://frankwykoff.com/robert_edgren.htm Illustration by Robert Edgren, "Miracle of Sport", July 10, 1928] ==="Known for truthfulness"=== Edgren gained a reputation among his readers and his colleagues as being a straight shooter. As ''[[The New York Times]]'' opined at the time of his death:
Even-tempered always, well-informed in all sports and particularly in boxing, to which he paid much notice, he was known the world over as an authority who always told the truth as he saw the events he watched.
It is a testimony to his integrity that in those days in New York, when the law did not permit the giving of decisions in fights, the wide world was willing to accept the judgment of Bob Edgren in deciding wagers made. When Bob Edgren, in his ''Evening World'' column, said so-and-so was the winner nobody complained.
==Declining health and death in California== Edgren was seriously injured in an automobile accident in the 1930s. He emerged from several weeks of hospitalization apparently recovered. He was appointed to the California Boxing Commission by Governor [[James Rolph]], resigning in 1932 because of ill health. His health declined and he was bedridden for some time before he died at his apartment at the [[Monterey Peninsula Country Club]] in [[Del Monte, California]] on September 9, 1939.{{cite news |author= |title=Bob Edgren Dead. Noted Cartoonist.
